reviews.review:
This was a TRIUMPH. 
I'm making a note here: HUGE success. It's hard to overstate my satisfaction.

Algo que comenzo como un simple prototipo conocido como Narbacular Drop tenrmino siendo conocido como Portal. Esta obra nos presenta un viaje de habilidad y logica en un entorno de primeras sencillo y a la larga algo sombrio. Inclusiones como el momentum y la ligereza de movimiento (como aguantar caidas grandes o incluso girar pronunciadamente en el aire) que posee nuestra protagonista ayudan a formar una experiencia jugable muy bien formada y muy comoda de controlar. En cuanto al desarrollo de la trama es similar a Half-Life (1998) en el sentido de que no posee grandes giros argumentales. Recomendable.

While I feel this should go without saying at this point, Portal is an excellent puzzle game that anyone can play and beat, even those usually not big into the genre. While released as a freeware title inside the orange box at first, Portal feels like an indie title through its lack of any cutscenes, focus on gameplay, and lonely eerie tone. As the title suggests, you use futuristic portals to solve puzzles. Using a special gun, you place blue and orange portals that only link when both are placed on most surfaces. Portals transport you and other objects instantly through the other side, and your momentum is carried over, even when your direction and angle changes. Using this system and other obstacles like switches, boxes, and turrets, you complete challenges room by room until the very end of the game. Unlike other puzzle games, there is no forced time limit to complete puzzles other than occasional death, meaning that you are free to let your mind experiment on solving and not fretting over impending time. All puzzles in this game are creative, unique, and challenge your brain to think of creative solutions. As someone who is not good at puzzles, I never had to consult a guide or ask for assistance during this game. Puzzles are first small, gradually increasing in difficulty and scope. Gameplay is always the focus, and while object placement can be janky, the gameplay is nearly perfect. In perfect Valve fashion, all story is told through gameplay, still engaging the player without stopping them or slowing the game down. The testing theme, lack of music, high tech setting, passive aggressive threatening by the AI system and progressive danger of puzzles leave you feeling like a true lab rat. This gives the whole game  a sense of pseudo horror and unique character. As a proof of concept game and freeware inclusion inside of the orange box, there is no multi player and the campaign is very short. Even then, extra levels and speed optimization leaves some level of replayability. The very small price tag on Steam helps ease this fact, especially when on sale for even less. Overall this gets an 8/10 for solid mechanics, strong atmosphere, and creative freedom that lets anyone think with portals.

very good for playing at home while feeling boring

Thank you for helping us help you help us all.

PROS: This is a triumph!  The puzzles are tight, well designed, and provide you with all the information you need to solve them.  They aren't exactly brain taxing, just enough to provide a solid challenge.  The maps are nice to look at, especially the last stage.  The sounds all have their own note to tell what's around the corner, and the few music tracks amp up the sensations running at the time.  The best is Ellen McLain's performance as GLaDOS.  The dark humor mixed with casual compliments and insults just skyrocket the quips to a whole new level.

CONS: The story is a little lacking, though it opts to keep the fluff off to keep things nice and punchy.  The only real issue is that the last level, while something fresh to look at, can be a tad confusing or annoying to sort through, depending on the player.

ACHIEVEMENTS: These are a real hiccup to complete.  The majority can be moved through, with some having slightly different challenges to them, such as removing cameras.  Getting all the gold medals is an absolute chore, and many will find them not worth completing due to the rather steep curve to complete a few.

FINAL: Portal is a magnificently designed puzzle game with great humor, fun puzzles, and a great mechanic in the portal gun to just seal the deal.  The small issues in the game are barely noticeable, and definitely not a deal breaker.  This is one of the must buy titles on Steam, and hands down is one of the better games you can play.

One of the best games ever made. I love Portal and Portal 2. Unfortunately it seems the game is not aging well. Because there's a bug that causes skipping audio and long freezes by the auto save feature. It's mostly just annoying. However it does make time challenges more difficult.

Still if you haven't had a chance to get on board with Portal it is still well worth playing.

Game: Portal
Overall Rating: 7/10
Ages: 8+, Some blood, that's it
Completion Time: 1-2 hours for main story, 8-10 hours for 100% completion + all achievements

--{GOOD}--
‚Ä¢ Very fun gameplay, challenging puzzles that progressively get harder with a unique concept of portals but I was able to complete the main game without any walkthroughs, getting all achievements was a bit harder though and required walkthroughs
‚Ä¢ The story is not too involved until the end, but enough to keep you engaged
‚Ä¢ Graphics are fine, especially for 2007 they hold up but not anything amazing
‚Ä¢ Does not require anything more than a laptop for 60 fps max settings
‚Ä¢ Did not encounter any bugs really although sometimes pulling things through portals was a bit annoying

--{BAD}--
‚Ä¢ Gets a little boring in some parts if you don't know what to do
‚Ä¢ Game is too short, I know it was more of a proof-of-concept for The Orange Box and not meant to be a fully fledged game but still felt like they could have made it longer than an hour with more challenges and extra content or longer main game
‚Ä¢ No soundtrack, you should crank some tunes and turn on subtitles in the middle but turn audio back on during the end

Worth:
‚òê Less than $5
‚òë $5 - $15
‚òê $15 - $30
‚òê $30 - $45
(I have never bought a game for more than this, and you shouldn‚Äôt either)

If you liked this game, you‚Äôll probably also like:
Portal 2
& Other indie puzzle games
